reviewText: NOTE:  I received a free copy of this DVD to review for the web site Metapsychology Online Reviews; please see a more detailed version of my review on that site.Instructor Angie Miller workouts out here with two background exercisers, Tania and Terrie.  Miller explains that she and Terrie will be using heavier weights (10 and 8 lbs.), while Tania will show modifications for some of the exercises.  In addition to the weights, they use a mat for the floorwork.On the case, this DVD is billed has having "3 Targeted Workouts":  Buff Body Blast, Booty Burner, and Core & Pelvic Floor.  However, there are actually a total of FIVE premixes; plus, you can do the workout in its entirety (approximately 60 minutes) OR choose individual sets, making this DVD extremely versatile.  (Note:  The "Buff Body Blast" workout mentioned on the DVD case simply refers to Sets 1-5.)The Main Menu offers the following options:  Play All -- Pre Mixes -- Into -- Warm Up -- Set One -- Set Two -- Set Three -- Set Four -- Set Five -- Booty Burner -- Core -- Stretch.  I have provided additional information on each segment below.WARM-UP (5 minutes)Miller leads basic moves such as marches, step-touches, hamstring curls, and knee-ups.  She concludes the warm-up with some dynamic stretching.SET 1 (<5 minutes)Here Miller uses her heavier weights and starts with a rear lunge.  She builds on this move, adding in an overhead press, bicep curl, and row, plus tempo variations as well.  To work on balance, Miller performs a step back (i.e., shallow curtsey lunge) and comes into a knee lift.SET 2 (6.5 minutes)This segment involves weaving the dumbbell around and through the legs, first in a squat position, then standing, moving under alternating knees in a Figure 8.  Next, Miller performs a deadlift/row combination, adding a press.  Finally, she repeats the Figure 8 in a wide-legged position.  (Note:  these moves can also be performed with a kettlebell.)SET 3 (7.5 minutes)This arms-focused set begins with a hammer curl, moves into a scapular rotation, and then transitions to a side biceps curl.  Miller follows this with several combination exercises, including a side/diagonal lunge with row and a triceps overhead press with knee balance.SET 4 (<4 minutes)Miller notes that this set is quick, yet intense.  She again focuses on balance by starting with a deadlift but then adding in a knee raise, a back lunge, and pulses; balance is made even trickier because she keeps alternating from side-to-side.SET 5 (5 minutes)In this last set, Miller performs kettlebell-like moves such as a wide upward row (similar to a high pull), clean and press, and windmill.  She concludes with a few pliés.BOOTY BURNER (10 minutes)For the first half of this segment, Miller and crew lie on their backs for pelvic tilts and bridge variations, including one-legged versions of the latter.  For the second part, they switch to an all-fours position.  Miller and Terrie use a weight behind one knee for various bent leg lifts, including crossover lifts and tempo changes.CORE (12 minutes)Miller begins the core work seated with the feet in a "clamshell" position (sort of an elevated butterfly) for small lifts.  They then move onto several variations of push-ups followed by an upward crab move.  Next is oblique work in a side-lying position, and the section concludes with a short series of "hovers."  This was my least favorite section--it seemed to target my hip flexors more than my abs, and it seemed more difficult than the rest of the DVD.STRETCH (5.5 minutes)Miller starts the stretch kneeling for a timed hip flexor stretch, moving into a hamstring stretch.  She walks forward into a standing forward bend, adding in a few variations here, including a twist.  Coming to standing, she concludes with some simple side, shoulder, and neck stretches.The Premix Submenu lists the following workout options:PREMIX ONE: BALANCE CHALLENGE  Sets 1 & 4PREMIX TWO: AMAZING ARMS  Sets 3, 4, 5PREMIX THREE: 20 MINUTE TOTAL BODY CHALLENGE  Sets 1, 3, 5PREMIX FOUR: 30 MINUTE COMPLETE WORKOUT  Sets 2, 4, 5, & CorePREMIX FIVE: CENTER STRONG  Booty Burner & CoreOverall, this is a well-done exercise DVD, with one of the main selling points being its versatility.  As she has with her previously workouts (includingCore and Strength FusionandKettlebell Bootcamp), Angie has made this DVD well-chaptered, making it very user-friendly.  Furthermore, Angie is encouraging, and she does inspire confidence as she expertly leads the workout.  The routines included here are challenging, and thus I would recommend this DVD mainly for experienced exercisers, ideally for those at an advanced beginner/low intermediate level or beyond.
summary: Nicely done, versatile DVD led by an experienced, motivating instructor

reviewText: A fun effective workout. Up the ante with extra poundage or a kettlebell. She moves from one interesting move to another and transforms her sets to pretty difficult without fanfare. Soon you are done and this hard workout is over.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I am an experienced home exerciser.  I use both DVD's and my elliptical.  I love this workout for a number of reasons.  Angie Miller's well structured workout is a super plus for a beginner.  She has two other exercisers in the video, one person is the beginner modifier and the other person shows a intermediate to advance exercises.  I really appreciated how she started easy with a lunge then would slightly advance twist to the lunge and finally she would incorporate balance and core development in the final version of the lunge.  Now that is just an example of  the lunge.  She does other types of modifications to challenge the home exerciser.  I use the word challenge mainly for those who are beginners or solid intermediates.  I tried to listen for the so called verbal tics mentioned in other reviews.  I didn't notice any because I was paying attention to her instruction and observing her form.  She is what I would consider an instructor's instructor.  It is apparent that her previous career path as a teacher impacts her style of instruction.  I actually like listening to her voice.  It isn't a chirpy or peppy style.  Yet, I can still sense her warmth in her mannerisms.  She isn't a drill sergeant in the manner of Jillian Michael's.  I would consider Angie Miller the 'grace kelly' of exercise DVD's.  She is well put together in her delivery and appearance.  This particular routine can be intense just based on the amount of weight used.  This is not HIIT training.  She does give detailed instruction.  I am only guessing that those who find her talkative would feel this after watching the DVD several times. I don't pay much attention to this particular criticism because it is moot since assuming one bought the video to be instructed by the person demonstrating the exercise.  I enjoyed this video a lot and highly recommend it for those looking for a workout that doesn't kill you on the first try.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I really enjoyed this DVD, it provides a thorough all-over body workout!  This is my 2nd Angie Miller DVD.  I have her Kettlebell Bootcamp which has a lot of the same moves as this workout.  The only reason I'm giving this a 4 star instead of a 5 star is because she really doesn't give you any chance to stretch after doing different routines...just make sure you have the remote nearby so you can pause when you feel you need a little stretch.  Other than that, I highly recommend this workout because it's a nice total body low-impact workout!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I am new to Angie Miller and this is the second DVD of hers that I have tried.  I discovered her this past summer by trying out her Kettlebell Bootcamp DVD, which is another great workout.Dr. Beth has already given a nice breakdown so I will just add my thoughts.  I think this is a very versatile DVD, you can do the main workout which runs over 30 minutes, the booty burner and core workouts, or choose from one of the premixes.  This routine requires very little equipment only a few sets of dumbells.  Angie uses 8's and 10's.  I used 5's, an 8 and a 10 pounder.  For some of the exercises a 10 pounder is just right, but other exercises were they are moving a little fast, it was almost a little too heavy for me so my 8 pounder worked perfectly.This workout contains a lot of compound movements, some of which include core and balance work.  As I get older I am realize the importance of these exercises.  I have always preferred more traditional strength work, and while I still enjoy it and do it regularly, I am incorporating more of this type of functional training in my workouts, along with some kettlebell work.  I think that it mixes it up nicely and I don't adapt to the same type of routine.  Angie does compound movements very well, in a way her style reminds me a little of the Firm which I have been a long time fan of.The lower body floorwork and core sections are short but good.  Angie does include a modifier that shows you options for some of the more difficult core exercises.  I would rate this workout intermediate, though beginners could lighten up on the weights, and advanced could heavy up a little.All in all this is one of my best buys of the year.  I see myself using this workout a lot, Angie says in the introduction that this workout is the first of the Bedroom Body series.  I will definitely be interested in what workouts follow this one.Overall, I rate this workout 4 and a half stars.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I really like this workout.  I love that she does enough reps to really feel the muscles work.  I hate when instructors rush through the set.  The time really flew by and of course I loved that!  She gives good instruction.... a little chatty...a little annoying with the "yeah?".  I think it's just her midwestern accent though.  I really felt this the next day.  The music could be better but it's not so bad that I wouldn't want to do the workout again.  I like the way you have options of doing different premixes for those days when you don't have time to do the entire DVD.  All in all, I will probably be doing this one a lot.
summary: Great Variety, Easy to Follow, Fun!
